facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 35 of 1955 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JUIRISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 35 of 1955. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 10, 1952, of the Calcutta High Court

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and decree dated March 10, 1952, of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 10, 1952, of the Calcutta High Court in appeal from the Original Order No. 100 of 1950 arising out of the decree dated July 18, 1950,

facts.text: Original Order No. 100 of 1950 of Subordinate Judge, Alipore, 2nd Court, arising out of decree dated July 18, 1950, in Miscellaneous Case No. 76 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: in appeal from the Original Order No. 100 of 1950 arising out of the decree dated July 18, 1950, of the Court of Subordinate Judge, Alipore, 2nd Court, in Miscellaneous Case No. 76 of 1949.

facts.text: Ramani Kanta Roy possessed considerable properties.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading thereto are as follows. One Ramani Kanta Roy was possessed of companysiderable properties. He had three sons, Rajes Kanta Roy, Rabindra Kanta Roy and Ramendra Kanta Roy.

facts.text: Ramani had three sons: Rajes Kanta Roy, Rabindra Kanta Roy, Ramendra Kanta Roy.

anchor.surface_text: He had three sons, Rajes Kanta Roy, Rabindra Kanta Roy and Ramendra Kanta Roy. Rabindra died childless in the year 1938 leaving a widow, Santi Debi.

facts.text: Rabindra died childless in 1938 leaving widow Santi Debi.

anchor.surface_text: Rabindra died childless in the year 1938 leaving a widow, Santi Debi. ln 1934 Ramani created an endowment in respect of some of his properties in favour of his family deity

facts.text: In 1934 Ramani created endowment for family deity, appointed three sons as shebaits.

anchor.surface_text: ln 1934 Ramani created an endowment in respect of some of his properties in favour of his family deity and appointed his three sons as shebaits. After the death of Rabindra his widow Santi Debi,

facts.text: In 1941 Santi Debi instituted suit against family members for declaration as shebait, terminated in compromise recognizing her right.

anchor.surface_text: instituted a suit against the other members of the family in 1941 for a declaration that she, as the heir of her deceased husband, was entitled to function as a shebait in the place of her husband. The suit terminated in a companypromise

facts.text: In 1944 Ramani and sons Rajes and Ramendra filed suit against Santi Debi claiming 1941 compromise null and void, ground marriage nullity.

anchor.surface_text: recognizing the right of Salnti Debi as a companyhebait. Shortly thereafter, however, i.e., in the year 1944, Ramani and his two sons, Rajes and Ramendra, filed a suit against Santi Debi. for a declaration that the above mentioned companypromise decree was null and void.

facts.text: On July 26, 1945, Ramani executed registered trust deed over entire properties, appointed Rajes sole trustee.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of that suit Ramani, the father, executed a registered trust deed in respect of his entire properties on July 26, 1945. The terms of that trust-deed will be referred to presently.

facts.text: Ramani died after execution of trust deed, exact date not on record.

anchor.surface_text: After the execution of this trust deed the father died, The exact date of his death does number appear on the record.

facts.text: Suit compromised on December 3, 1946; Santi gave up 1941 rights, agreed to Rs.475 monthly for life, payable from Nov 1946, executable on default.

anchor.surface_text: Some time thereafter the suit was companypromised on December 3, 1946. The material terms of this companypromise will be set out presently. By the said companypromise Santi Debi gave up her rights under the previous companypromise decree of 1941

facts.text: Monthly allowance paid regularly up to end of February 1948, thereafter defaulted.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the monthly allowance as aforesaid was regularly paid up to the end of February, 1948, and that thereafter payment was defaulted.

facts.text: Santi Debi filed execution application on July 8, 1949, for arrears March 1948 to July 1949, Rs.8,075 against Rajes and Ramendra, attachment of 44/2 Lansdowne Road.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently Santi Debi filed an application for execution on July 8, 1949, to realise the arrears of her monthly allowance from March, 1948, to July, 1949, amounting to Rs. 8,075 against both the brothers, Rajes and Ramendra.

facts.text: Rajes filed objection under s.47 CPC to execution.

anchor.surface_text: Rajes filecl an objection to the execution under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure on various grounds. Ramendra has number filed, or joined in, any such application

facts.text: Subordinate Judge overruled Rajes' objections.

anchor.surface_text: An order was passed by the Subordinate Judge over-ruling the objections raised by Rajes. An appeal was taken therefrom to the High Court at Calcutta

facts.text: Calcutta High Court dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: which was dismissed by its judgment under appeal. Hence the present appeal in which Rajes is the appellant, while Santi Debi is the first respondent

facts.text: Compromise decree charges Bharatkhali property for monthly allowance.

anchor.surface_text: That the properties mentioned in the schedule below are hereby charged for the due payment of the said monthly allowance and the defendant No. 1 will be at liberty to realise the amount in default against the properties charged

facts.text: Rajes contends no attachable interest in properties under trust deed.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of the deed of trust Rajes has numberattachable interest in the properties sought to be proceeded against.

facts.text: Court holds Rajes' interest under trust deed is vested, not contingent, attachable.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that in so far as the interest of Rajes is companycerned in lots I to IV under the trust deed, it is vested and number companytingent.

facts.text: Execution sought against premises No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road, Ballygunge.

anchor.surface_text: Execution was asked for by way of attachment and sale of immovable properties,viz., premises No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road, Ballygunge P.S., 24- Parganas.

facts.text: Ramendra did not contest execution.

anchor.surface_text: Ramendra has number filed, or joined in, any such application and has apparently number companytested the execution.

facts.text: Trust terminates after liquidation of debts and death of settlor.

anchor.surface_text: it is only after the happening of the two events, viz.,  1  the discharge of all the debts specified in the schedules  including the debts, if any, that may be incurred by the trustee for payment of the settlors debts , and  2  the death of the settlor himself,

facts.text: Lots I-IV devolve on Rajes absolutely, subject to cl. c for 44/2 Lansdowne Road.

anchor.surface_text: The properties being Lot I, Lot II, Lot III, and Lot IV described in the said Schedule A hereunder written including the surplus income thereof shall devolve on the said Rajes Kanta Roy absolutely

holdings.text: There is an executable decree as the solenama forms part of the decree according to Bengal practice and execution cannot be defeated on the ground of no formal direction.

anchor.surface_text: But there can be no doubt that this was what was meant to be conveyed by the above mentioned formal order in so far as it is relevant for the present purposes. We understand that the actual decree in this case merely showing that the solenama do form part

holdings.reasoning_summary: Solenama recorded as part of decree per usual Bengal court practice; no indication point raised below; overruling minor objection.

holdings.text: Under the compromise decree, the personal remedy under cl. c is unqualified and available without first exhausting the charge under cls. d and e, which provide optional liberties.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the contention raised to the effect that the personal remedy is not available in this case before exhausting the charged properties, is not sustainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of cls. c, d, e shows cl. c gives unqualified right to execute personally; d and e are liberties/options not limiting c; intention clear from terms, no need to follow Bombay cases.

holdings.text: The interest of Rajes in lots I to IV under the trust deed is vested and not contingent, hence attachable.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that in so far as the interest of Rajes is concerned in lots I to IV under the trust deed, it is vested and not contingent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bias favouring vested interest unless contrary clear; entire income applied for benefit of donees (including debts as sons liable under Hindu law); surplus devolves per allotment; heirs provision; contemporaneous conduct charging interest.

holdings.text: The interest of Rajes in premises No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road under the trust deed is also vested (not different), though enjoyment restricted until alternative accommodation provided to Ramendra.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us reasonably clear that the intention of the settlor, taking cls. 12 a and c together, is that as regards Lots I to IV, the beneficial interest of Rajes as regards all the properties comprised therein, including premises No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road, is vested in title but restricted in enjoyment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subjection to cl. c affects only absolute devolution post-trust termination; no ownership gap during trust; cl. 12 terminates trust on debts/settlor death for all lots; restriction on enjoyment not vesting.

holdings.text: The objections to execution on grounds of charge exhaustion and contingent interest are untenable.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the objection raised to the execution 1 on the ground that the properties charged are to be proceeded against, in the first instance, and 2 on the ground that the interest which Rajes gets under the trust deed either as regards the general properties covered by the deed or as regards premises No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road, is contingent, are untenable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Summarising resolutions of main issues; execution proceeds.

precedents.citation: Pestonjee Bhicajee v. P. H. Anderson 1

anchor.surface_text: Pestonjee Bhicajee v. P. H. Anderson 1 . The question as to whether the interest of the judgment-debtor, Rajes, in this case is vested or contingent, is one not altogether free from difficulty. But it is well to notice at the outset that this point has not been raised in the petition filed by the judgment-debtor, Rajes, under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure. What is stated therein is merely the following Under the said deed of trust, the judgment debtor has nointerest in the property except that of a trustee and as such the decree holder cannot proceed for realisation of her alleged dues against the said property. The objection in this form is obviously untenable and has not been urged in any of the courts below. Indeed, if under the trust deed the judgment-debtor has a beneficial interest, it is not disputed that such beneficial interest would be attachable provided it is a vested interest and not a contingent interest.

precedents.case_name: Pestonjee Bhicajee v P H Anderson
precedents.cited_proposition: mere contingent interest though transferable inter vivos is not attachable

precedents.citation: Ranganatha Mudaliar v. A. Mohana Krishna Mudaliar 1

anchor.surface_text: Ranganatha Mudaliar v. A. Mohana Krishna Mudaliar 1 . The learned Solicitor General appearing for the appellant before us has urged that there is no such inflexible rule of law as is assumed by the High Court, viz., that in spite of a clause requiring payment of debts before the property reaches the hands of the donee, the gift is a vested one. He drew our attention to the fact that both s. 19 of the Transfer of Property Act and s. 119 of the Indian Succession Act clearly indicate that if a contrary intention appears from the document that will prevail.

precedents.case_name: Ranganatha Mudaliar v A Mohana Krishna Mudaliar
precedents.cited_proposition: in spite of a clause requiring payment of debts before the property reaches the hands of the donee, the gift is a vested one

anchor.surface_text: Bernard v. Mountague 2 in which it was held, on a construction of the terms of the trust, that the payment of the debts was a condition precedent to the vesting of the interest devised therein. How, such a matter, as the one before us, is treated in English law when it arises, appears from the following passages in the recognised textbooks. Williams on Executors and Administrators 13th Ed. , Vol. 2, at p. 658, states one of the two rules of construction to be that where the bequest -is in terms immediate, and the payment alone postponed, the legacy is vested.

precedents.cited_proposition: payment of the debts was a condition precedent to the vesting of the interest
precedents.cited_holding: payment of the debts was a condition precedent to the vesting of the interest devised therein

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the objection raised to the execution  1  on the ground that the properties charged are to be proceeded against, in the first instance, and  2  on the ground that the interest which Rajes gets under the trust deed either as regards the general properties companysidered by the deed or as regards premises No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road, is companytingent, are untenable.

outcome.relief_summary: Objections under s.47 to execution proceedings overruled; personal remedy available without exhausting charge; Rajes' interest in properties held vested and attachable

edges.explanation: Argument that dues realizable only from charged property addresses whether personal remedy requires exhaustion of charge
